tool.name: arcchordratio

param.name: Area of Interest
param.dialogReference:
A feature class containing one or more polygons that define the area of interest of the input surface raster for which the arc-chord ratio will be calculated. The results of this tool will be added to the value table of the area of interest. These results include the ACR rugosity, the surface area and planar area of the area of interest, and the slope and aspect of the area of interest (both in units of degrees).

If a multipart geometry is given, it will be converted to a collection of single-part geometries.

param.name: Save TINs
param.displayname: Save Output Contoured and Planar TINs
param.dialogReference:
If this parameter is enabled, all TINs will be saved to the output workspace specified. If this parameter is enabled and the 'Output Workspace' field is left blank, all TINs will be saved to the parent directory of the Area of Interest.

This tool creates several TINs (Triangulated Irregular Networks) in the process of calculating results. The first TIN directly represents the input bathymetric dataset. Then, a TIN is created to represent the plane of best fit of each polygon in the area of interest. These TINs are by default deleted after this tool completes; however, the TINs may be useful for visualizing the rugosity of the study area.

tool.summary:
Calculates the arc-chord ratio (ACR) rugosity index of a bathymetric dataset for the extent of the area of interest (AOI) defined. The ACR rugosity index is a measure of three-dimensional structural complexity that is independent of slope at the scale of the surface.

ACR is calculated by creating two TINs, one representing the input dataset and one representing the plane of best fit (POBF) of the AOI. The POBF is a function (interpolation) of the boundary data only of the area of interest. The surface area of the first TIN within the AOI is divided by that of the second TIN to obtain a single ACR value for the area of interest. For more information on this metric please see Dupreez (2014).

Note: Results from this tool will be added as new columns to the AOI polygon dataset chosen. If multipart polygons are used as an input, each will be exploded into separate polygons using the Multipart to Singlepart tool, and linked back to their original polygons with the ORIG_FID column.

References:

Du Preez, C. "A new arc-chord ratio (ACR) rugosity index for quantifying three-dimensional landscape structural complexity." Landscape Ecology. 2014, 30, 181–192.
tool.usage:
• Results of this tool will be stored in the value table of the area(s) of interest.

  • The slope and aspect of the plane of best fit will be automatically computed. These can be helpful descriptors of the area of interest in addition to the arc-chord ratio.

  • To create a surface of arc-chord ratio rugosity, rather than a single value for an area of interest, please use the Surface Area to Planar Area tool.
